title: Problem Overview
content: Erdős Problem #385 defines F(n) = max{m + p(m) : m < n composite} where p(m) is the least prime divisor. Question 1: F(n) > n for large n? Question 2: F(n) - n → ∞?

title: Composite Numbers
content: A number n is composite if n > 1 and n is not prime. These are exactly the numbers with non-trivial factorizations: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, ...

title: Least Prime Divisor
content: For n > 1, p(n) is the smallest prime dividing n. For composite n, p(n) ≤ √n (key property). We use Mathlib's minFac which computes this efficiently.

title: The Function F(n)
content: F(n) = max{m + p(m) : m < n, m composite}. We take the maximum of m + p(m) over all composite m less than n. This measures how far composite values can 'reach beyond' n.

title: Trivial Upper Bound
content: F(n) ≤ n + √n. Since any composite m < n has p(m) ≤ √m ≤ √n, we get m + p(m) < n + √n. This is tight asymptotically.

title: Question 1 (OPEN)
content: Is F(n) > n for all sufficiently large n? Equivalently: for large n, can we always find a composite m < n with m + p(m) > n? Plausible prime conjectures imply this.

title: Question 2 (OPEN)
content: Does F(n) - n → ∞ as n → ∞? This is stronger than Question 1, asking not just that F(n) exceeds n but that the excess grows without bound.

title: Connection to Problem #430
content: Sarosh Adenwalla observed Question 1 is equivalent to Problem #430. This asks about the same phenomenon from different angles - density of composites with large m + p(m).

title: Concrete Example
content: F(10) = 12, achieved by m = 9 with p(9) = 3 so 9 + 3 = 12. The composites below 10 are {4,6,8,9} giving sums {6,8,10,12}. Here F(10) > 10. ✓

title: Conjectured Lower Bound
content: It's conjectured that F(n) ≥ n + (1 - o(1))√n, meaning we can always find m < n composite with m + p(m) close to n + √n (the upper bound). Gap is o(√n).

title: Why This Is Hard
content: The problem connects to prime distribution, the parity problem in sieve theory, and Siegel zeros (discussed by Terry Tao). Proving F(n) > n requires understanding when composites with small p(m) appear close to n.

title: Summary
content: Both questions remain OPEN. F(n) ≤ n + √n is trivial. Conjecturally F(n) ≥ n + (1-o(1))√n. Related to Problems #430, #463, and OEIS A322292. Terry Tao connected it to Siegel zeros.
